column¶

conversion¶

Alias for field number 1

bi_etl.conversions.bytes2human(n, format_str='%(value).1f %(symbol)s', symbols='customary')[source]¶

Convert n bytes into a human readable string based on format_str. symbols can be either “customary”, “customary_ext”, “iec” or “iec_ext”, see: http://goo.gl/kTQMs

>>> bytes2human(0)
'0.0 B'
>>> bytes2human(0.9)
'0.0 B'
>>> bytes2human(1)
'1.0 B'
>>> bytes2human(1.9)
'1.0 B'
>>> bytes2human(1024)
'1.0 K'
>>> bytes2human(1048576)
'1.0 M'
>>> bytes2human(1099511627776127398123789121)
'909.5 Y'

>>> bytes2human(9856, symbols="customary")
'9.6 K'
>>> bytes2human(9856, symbols="customary_ext")
'9.6 kilo'
>>> bytes2human(9856, symbols="iec")
'9.6 Ki'
>>> bytes2human(9856, symbols="iec_ext")
'9.6 kibi'

>>> bytes2human(10000, "%(value).1f %(symbol)s/sec")
'9.8 K/sec'

>>> # precision can be adjusted by playing with %f operator
>>> bytes2human(10000, format_str="%(value).5f %(symbol)s")
'9.76562 K'
bi_etl.conversions.change_tz(source_datetime, from_tzone, to_tzone)[source]¶

Change time-zones in dates that have no time-zone info, or incorrect time-zone info

Example from_tzone or to_tzone values:

pytz.utc
pytz.timezone('US/Eastern')
bi_etl.conversions.defaultInvalid(v)[source]¶

Same as nvl(v, ‘Invalid’)

bi_etl.conversions.defaultMissing(v)[source]¶

Same as nvl(v, ‘Missing’)

bi_etl.conversions.defaultNines(v)[source]¶

Same as nvl(v, -9999)

bi_etl.conversions.defaultQuestionmark(v)[source]¶

Same as nvl(v, ‘?’)

bi_etl.conversions.human2bytes(s)[source]¶

Attempts to guess the string format based on default symbols set and return the corresponding bytes as an integer. When unable to recognize the format ValueError is raised.

>>> human2bytes('0 B')
0
>>> human2bytes('1 K')
1024
>>> human2bytes('1 M')
1048576
>>> human2bytes('1 Gi')
1073741824
>>> human2bytes('1 tera')
1099511627776

>>> human2bytes('0.5kilo')
512
>>> human2bytes('0.1  byte')
0
>>> human2bytes('1 k')  # k is an alias for K
1024
>>> human2bytes('12 foo')
Traceback (most recent call last):
    ...
ValueError: can't interpret '12 foo'
bi_etl.conversions.nullif(v, value_to_null)[source]¶

Pass value through unchanged unless it is equal to provided value_to_null value. If v ==`value_to_null` value then return NULL (None)

bi_etl.conversions.nvl(v, default)[source]¶

Pass value through unchanged unless it is NULL (None). If it is NULL (None), then return provided default value.

bi_etl.conversions.replace_tilda(e)[source]¶

Used for unicode error to replace invalid ascii with ~

bi_etl.conversions.str2bytes_size(str_size)[source]¶

Parses a string containing a size in bytes including KB, MB, GB, TB codes into an integer with the actual number of bytes (using 1 KB = 1024).

bi_etl.conversions.str2date(s, dt_format='%m/%d/%Y')[source]¶

Parse a date (no time) value stored in a string.

Parameters:
  • s (str) – String value to convert
  • dt_format (str) – For format options please see https://docs.python.org/3.5/library/datetime.html#strftime-strptime-behavior
bi_etl.conversions.str2datetime(s, dt_format='%m/%d/%Y %H:%M:%S')[source]¶

Parse a date + time value stored in a string.

Parameters:
  • s (str) – String value to convert
  • dt_format (str) – For format options please see https://docs.python.org/3.5/library/datetime.html#strftime-strptime-behavior
bi_etl.conversions.str2decimal(s)[source]¶

String to decimal (AKA numeric)

bi_etl.conversions.str2decimal_end_sign(s)[source]¶

String to decimal (AKA numeric). This version is almost 4 times faster than tr2decimal in handling signs at the end of the string.

bi_etl.conversions.str2float(s)[source]¶

String to floating point

bi_etl.conversions.str2float_end_sign(s)[source]¶

String to integer This version is almost 4 times faster than str2float in handling signs at the end of the string.

bi_etl.conversions.str2int(s)[source]¶

String to integer

bi_etl.conversions.str2time(s, dt_format='%H:%M:%S')[source]¶

Parse a time of day value stored in a string.

Parameters:
  • s (str) – String value to convert
  • dt_format (str) – For format options please see https://docs.python.org/3.5/library/datetime.html#strftime-strptime-behavior
